stem: The patient is a 68-year-old male presenting with acute right-sided weakness and slurred speech. His NIHSS score is 12. Review the patient chart and identify the priority intervention.

patient.chiefComplaint: Sudden onset right-sided weakness and slurred speech

itemContext.sbar:
14:00, Patient is a 68-year-old male presenting with acute right-sided weakness and slurred speech, onset approximately 1 hour prior to arrival. NIHSS score is 12. Last known well was this morning at 08:00. Patient has a history of hypertension and hyperlipidemia.

options.text: Initiate stroke protocol and obtain a CT scan of the head without contrast.
options.feedback: Correct: Initiating the stroke protocol and obtaining a CT scan of the head without contrast is the priority. This is crucial to determine if the patient is experiencing an ischemic or hemorrhagic stroke, which will dictate further treatment.
Incorrect: Administering aspirin before confirming the type of stroke (ischemic vs. hemorrhagic) can be harmful. A CT scan is needed first.

options.text: Consult physical therapy for mobility assessment.
options.feedback: Incorrect: Consulting physical therapy is important for rehabilitation but is not the priority in the acute setting. Determining the type of stroke and initiating appropriate treatment takes precedence.

options.text: Administer antihypertensive medication to reduce blood pressure below 140/90 mmHg.
options.feedback: Incorrect: Permissive hypertension is often allowed in acute ischemic stroke to maintain cerebral perfusion. Rapidly lowering blood pressure can be detrimental.

rationale.correct: Initiating the stroke protocol and obtaining a CT scan of the head without contrast is the priority. This is crucial to determine if the patient is experiencing an ischemic or hemorrhagic stroke, which will dictate further treatment. Rapid identification of the stroke type guides subsequent interventions, such as thrombolytics for ischemic stroke or blood pressure management for hemorrhagic stroke.
rationale.incorrect: Administering aspirin before confirming the type of stroke (ischemic vs. hemorrhagic) can be harmful. A CT scan is needed first to rule out hemorrhage. Consulting physical therapy is important for rehabilitation but is not the priority in the acute setting. Determining the type of stroke and initiating appropriate treatment takes precedence. Permissive hypertension is often allowed in acute ischemic stroke to maintain cerebral perfusion. Rapidly lowering blood pressure can be detrimental.
clinicalPearls: Time is brain in stroke management. Rapid assessment and intervention are critical.
A CT scan without contrast is the initial imaging modality to differentiate between ischemic and hemorrhagic stroke.
Permissive hypertension is often allowed in acute ischemic stroke to maintain cerebral perfusion.
The NIHSS score helps quantify the severity of the stroke and guide treatment decisions.

questionTrap.commonMistake: Prioritizing interventions that may be harmful before diagnosis (e.g., aspirin in hemorrhagic stroke) or delaying critical diagnostic procedures. Forgetting the importance of rapid diagnosis via CT scan.
questionTrap.reasoningError: Failing to recognize the need to differentiate between ischemic and hemorrhagic stroke before initiating treatment.

mnemonic.name: FAST
mnemonic.description: Face, Arm, Speech, Time - to recognize stroke symptoms quickly.
mnemonic.application: This mnemonic helps with rapid recognition of stroke symptoms, emphasizing the importance of immediate action. Act FAST!
